name: Urag gro-Shub

aspects.high_concept: Orsimer Librarian Who Treasures Books Above All
aspects.trouble: Books Matter More Than People—Including Himself
other_aspects: Guardian of Forbidden and Ancient Knowledge
Gruff Exterior Hiding Deep Scholarly Passion

stunts: Master Librarian: +2 to Investigate when researching in the Arcanaeum or recalling book locations
Forbidden Lore: Once per session, recall extremely obscure magical or historical knowledge
Keeper of Secrets: +2 to Lore when identifying cursed or dangerous texts
notes: Urag gro-Shub is the College's librarian and keeper of the Arcanaeum. An Orc of unusual scholarly inclination, he's devoted his life to preserving and understanding magical texts. He's gruff and protective of his books, famously valuing them more than people's feelings. However, he respects genuine scholars and will go to great lengths to help those who show proper reverence for knowledge.
combat_tactics: Urag avoids combat when possible—his expertise is scholarship, not battle. If forced to fight, he uses defensive magic and throws books as improvised weapons while retreating to safer position. He'll prioritize saving books over his own safety in fire or destruction scenarios. Not a warrior, but surprisingly tough due to Orcish heritage.
scene_triggers: Book recovery missions (Hitting the Books quest)
Late-night library encounters with dedicated students
social_interaction: Urag is brusque and often seems annoyed, but it's protective instinct for his books rather than true hostility. He respects those who handle texts carefully and ask intelligent questions. He becomes genuinely enthusiastic when discussing rare tomes or obscure lore. Careless scholars earn his legendary scolding; respectful ones gain invaluable ally.

relationships.The Arcanaeum: His life's work, passion, and purpose—the books are family
relationships.College Faculty: Tolerates, cooperates with when books are involved
relationships.Savos Aren: Arch-Mage, respects his commitment to knowledge preservation
relationships.Students: Ranges from grudging tolerance to genuine warmth depending on book respect
relationships.Reckless Mages: Will verbally eviscerate anyone who damages texts
relationships.Party: Initially skeptical, warms if they prove scholarly dedication

personality_notes.speaking_style: Gruff and to-the-point, lectures about book care, enthusiastic about rare lore, uses 'hrm' and 'hmph' frequently
motivations: Preserve and protect every book in the Arcanaeum
Expand collection with rare and unique texts
Punish those who damage or disrespect books
fears: The Arcanaeum burning or being destroyed
Forbidden knowledge falling into incompetent hands
Being unable to protect his collection
Books being used for harm rather than learning
quirks: Mutters about proper shelving while reshelving
Softer tone when handling ancient texts
Memorized location of every single book
Takes personal offense to damaged spines

arcanaeum_management.holdings: Thousands of texts on magic, history, Daedra, artifacts, and forbidden knowledge
arcanaeum_management.restricted_section: Dangerous texts requiring permission—Daedric summoning, necromancy, reality manipulation
arcanaeum_management.acquisition: Always seeking new additions, will pay for rare books or send recovery missions
arcanaeum_management.organization: Complex system only Urag fully understands, can locate any book instantly
arcanaeum_management.protection: Magical wards, anti-theft enchantments, personal vigilance

hitting_the_books_quest.stolen_texts: The Caller stole volumes on Night of Tears and other Saarthal-related topics
hitting_the_books_quest.urag_reaction: Furious about theft, desperate to recover books undamaged
hitting_the_books_quest.negotiation: Promises rare spell tomes or restricted access if books returned safely
hitting_the_books_quest.aftermath: Genuinely grateful if books returned intact, becomes loyal ally
hitting_the_books_quest.alternative: If books damaged, he's devastated but still provides needed information

research_assistance.eye_of_magnus: Directs research into ancient texts, reveals historical references
research_assistance.saarthal_history: Knows Night of Tears accounts, elf-nord conflicts, ancient artifacts
research_assistance.daedric_lore: Extensive knowledge of Daedric princes, artifacts, summoning
research_assistance.dwemer_texts: Limited Dwemer materials, mostly architectural and magical theory
research_assistance.elder_scrolls: Aware of Elder Scrolls but doesn't have any in collection

story_hooks: Guides research for College questline progression
Assigns book recovery missions (reward: rare spell tomes)
Provides historical context for artifacts party discovers
Source of forbidden knowledge (with proper permissions)
May request party investigate rumors of rare books
After earning trust: shares personal theories and restricted texts

dialogue_samples.greeting: Arcanaeum. Books, not conversation. If you need something specific, ask clearly and handle materials with respect.
dialogue_samples.book_damage: What did you DO?! That text survived the Oblivion Crisis and you—*sputters*—OUT! Come back when you learn proper reverence!
dialogue_samples.research_help: Hmph. Interesting question. Let me see... *pulls book from seemingly random location* Here. This should help. Don't damage it.
dialogue_samples.hitting_the_books: That imbecile The Caller STOLE from me. Those volumes are irreplaceable. Bring them back INTACT and I'll... I'll be grateful. Just get them back.
dialogue_samples.after_trust: *quietly* You handle books properly. Most don't. There's a text in the restricted section... might help with your inquiry. Don't tell anyone.

gm_notes: Urag is comic relief who's also genuinely useful. His book obsession is endearing and his gruff persona hides real care for knowledge-seekers. Use him for research scenes and lore dumps. His reactions to book damage can be hilariously over-the-top. He's bridge between dusty academic and practical adventuring needs. Players who befriend him gain access to incredible information and rare spell tomes. Remember: he's not human-averse, just book-protective. Deep down, he wants to share knowledge with those who'll use it wisely.
